snippet: Exit polls for the Moscow mayoral election showed that the incumbent had narrowly won, but Aleksei A. Navalny, a prominent critic of President Vladimir V. Putin, asserted he had enough votes to force a second round.
abstract: First mayoral election in Moscow in a decade ends with a narrow victory for appointed incumbent Sergei S Sobyanin; Aleksei A Navalny, Sobyanin's main challenger and one of Pres Vladimir V Putin's most prominent critics, claims that he has won enough votes to force a runoff and warns of efforts to falsify outcome of race.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by David M. Herszenhorn, Andrew Roth, Noah Sneider, Viktor Klimenko and Sophia Kishkovsky.

lead_paragraph: Exit polls for the Moscow mayoral election showed that the incumbent had narrowly won, but Aleksei A. Navalny, a prominent critic of President Vladimir V. Putin, asserted he had enough votes to force a second round.

headline.main: Challenger in Race for Moscow Mayor Says He Can Force a Runoff
headline.print_headline: Challenger in Race for Moscow Mayor Says He Can Force a Runoff
